elements.content: New zinc(II) and cadmium(II) coordination polymers with 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato (L) bridging ligands have been synthesized by treating the metal salts and 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. [Zn(L)2]·(pyridine), 1, adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles. Large open channels formed in 1 are filled with included pyridine guest molecules. Both [Cd2(L)3(NO3)], 2, and [Cd4(L)6(ClO4)2(MeOH)2]·(H2O), 3, adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively. Crystal data for 1:  triclinic space group P1̄, a = 8.601(1), b = 12.364(1), c = 14.224(1) Å, α = 72.687(1), β = 88.118(1), γ = 71.679(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 2:  triclinic space group P1̄, a = 10.675(1), b = 12.671(1), c = 14.838(1) Å, α = 74.772(1), β = 88.283(1), γ = 73.671(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 3:  monoclinic space group P21, a = 13.165(3), b = 20.119(9), c = 15.446(6) Å, β = 95.19(3), Z = 2.

elements.content: Zinc(II) and cadmium(II) coordination polymers with 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato (L) bridging ligands were synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. [Zn(L)2]·(pyridine), 1, adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles, with its large open channels filled with pyridine guest molecules. [Cd2(L)3(NO3)], 2, and [Cd4(L)6(ClO4)2(MeOH)2]·(H2O), 3, adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively.

[Zn(L)2]⋅(pyridine), 1, adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles, with its large open channels filled with pyridine guest molecules. [Cd2(L)3(NO3)], 2, and [Cd4(L)6(ClO4)2(MeOH)2]⋅(H2O), 3, adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively.

elements.content: The field of solid-state supramolecular chemistry has undergone revolutionary growth over the past decade, motivated by the prospect of rationally generating many important functions such as second harmonic generation, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and gas sorption and storage. The modular nature of such a synthetic approach via the combination of organic bridging ligands and metallic nodes can lead to systematic tuning of a particular property. Major obstacles that prevent the realization of such crystal engineering of material functions lie in the complexity and general lack of predictability of solid-state structures formed from the combination of organic bridging ligands and metallic nodes. A detailed understanding of the structures of such complex hybrid inorganic−organic systems represents the first step toward the rational design of novel materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of solid-state supramolecular chemistry has undergone revolutionary growth over the past decade, motivated by the prospect of rationally generating many important functions such as second harmonic generation, magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, and gas sorption and storage. The modular nature of such a synthetic approach via the combination of organic bridging ligands and metallic nodes can lead to systematic tuning of a particular property. Major obstacles that prevent the realization of such crystal engineering of material functions lie in the complexity and general lack of predictability of solid-state structures formed from the combination of organic bridging ligands and metallic nodes. A detailed understanding of the structures of such complex hybrid inorganic-organic systems represents the first step toward the rational design of novel materials.

elements.content: Our group has recently explored the synthesis of interesting optical and magnetic materials via the use of unsymmetrical pyridinecarboxylate bridging ligands. The use of rigid, conjugated pyridinecarboxylate bridging ligands in our approach has greatly simplified the structural control on the resulting coordination networks. As an extension of this work, we have examined the reactions of bent precursor ligand 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile with zinc and cadmium salts under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. We report here the synthesis and X-ray structures of a novel 1D zinc coordination polymer built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles, and two 2D cadmium coordination polymers that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively.

Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All of the chemicals were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer Paragon 1000 FT-IR spectrometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of E -3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile. A mixture of (3-cyanobenzyl)triphenylphosphonium bromide (7.90 g, 17.2 mmol) and 3-pyridinecarbaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) in 25 mL of methylene chloride was stirred vigorously in a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask. To this suspension was added 8 mL of 50% aqueous NaOH dropwise over the course of 1 h. After the sample was stirred vigorously for one additional hour, the mixture was diluted with 50 mL of methylene chloride and washed with three portions of deionized water (100 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness. The residue was transferred to a 100 mL round-bottom flask containing iodine crystals (0.1 g, 0.788 mmol) and 50 mL of nitrobenzene, and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Upon cooling, the reaction mixture was extracted with dilute hydrochloric acid. The aqueous phase was removed, made alkaline with 3 M NaOH, and extracted with ethyl acetate. The extract was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness, and then purified by silica gel column chromatography (EtAc/hexane:  1/1) to afford 2.17 g of E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (51.7% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.60 (d, 4 J = 1.8 Hz, 1H, H1), 8.39 (dd, 3 J = 4.4 Hz, 4 J = 1.8 Hz, 1H, H2), 7.70 (dt, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 4 J = 1.6 Hz, 1H, H9), 7.62 (d, 4 J = 1.6 Hz, 1H, H10), 7.59 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H4), 7.39 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H7), 7.32 (dd, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H8), 7.16 (dd, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 3 J = 4.4 Hz, 1H, H3), 6.96 (s, 2H, H5 and H6). 13C {1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ 148.8, 148.2, 137.4, 132.5, 131.6, 130.7, 130.2, 129.5, 129.1, 127.7, 127.0, 123.2, 118.2, 112.4.

Synthesis of [Zn(L) 2 ]·(py), 1. A mixture of Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.038 g, 0.125 mmol) and E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (0.052 g, 0.25 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with EtOH (1.25 mL), H2O (0.25 mL), and pyridine (0.25 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen and sealed under vacuum, and placed inside an oven at 140 °C. After 40 days of heating, crystalline products of 1 were obtained. Yield:  0.048 g (64.8%). IR (cm-1):  3462 (m, br), 3030 (w), 2965 (w), 1606(m), 1589 (m), 1551(s), 1483 (m), 1410(m), 1400 (s), 1225 (m), 1194 (m), 1131 (w), 1087 (w), 1059 (s), 1029 (w), 993 (w), 962 (m), 927 (w), 874 (w), 824 (s) 803 (s), 772 (s), 760 (m), 649 (m), 604 (w), 548 (w).

elements.content: X-ray Collections and Structure Determination. X-ray single-crystal data collections for compounds 1−3 were carried out on a Siemens SMART system equipped with a CCD detector with Mo Kα radiation at 0.71073 Å. All three of the structures were solved by direct methods using SHELX-TL. All the non-hydrogen atoms of the framework structures in 1 were refined by full-matrix least squares using anisotropic displacement parameters, while the pyridine molecules were refined using isotropic displacement parameters. The position of the nitrogen atom on the pyridine guest molecule was not determined and all ring atoms were refined as carbon. All the hydrogen atoms of the framework structure in 1 were located by idealized geometric placing.

All the hydrogen atoms of the framework structure in 1 were located by idealized geometric placing.

Synthesis. Ligand precursor E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile was synthesized by a Wittig coupling reaction between (3-cyanobenzyl)triphenylphosphonium bromide and 3-pyridinecarbaldehyde followed by an iodine-catalyzed isomerization reaction in a 51.7% overall yield (Scheme ). Compound 1 was obtained in good yields by a hydro(solvo)thermal reaction between zinc nitrate and E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile in a mixture of ethanol, pyridine, and water at 140 °C (Scheme ). Compounds 2 and 3 were similarly obtained by treating E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile and cadmium nitrate and perchlorate, respectively (Scheme ). The IR spectra of 1−3 clearly show the presence of strong carboxylate peaks at ∼1550 cm-1 and 1400 cm-1. Such in situ hydrolysis of cyano groups to carboxylic acids under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions have been previously successfully utilized by our group to obtain X-ray diffraction quality single crystals of metal pyridinecarboxylate coordination networks.

elements.content: X-ray Single - Crystal Structure of 1. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study shows that 1 adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular macrocycles and crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄. The asymmetric unit consists of one zinc center, two L ligands, and one pyridine guest molecule (Figure ). Both L ligands adopt an exo-tridentate linkage with a coordinating pyridyl group and a chelating carboxylate group. The Zn1 center adopts a highly distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two chelating carboxylate groups. The cis angles range from 60.35(8) to 105.45(9)°.

elements.content: Each Zn center in 1 is bridged by two L ligands to two other Zn centers to form a 1D polymeric structure (Figure a). Two adjacent Zn centers and two L ligands form a 22-membered macrocycle, and interestingly, adjacent macrocycles are almost mutually perpendicular with a dihedral angle of 94.0°. Every other macrocycle of the 1D chain lie essentially in parallel to the bc plane to afford large open channels that are occupied by pyridine guest molecules (Figure b).

Two adjacent Zn centers and two L ligands form a 22-membered macrocycle, and interestingly, adjacent macrocycles are almost mutually perpendicular with a dihedral angle of 94.0°. Every other macrocycle of the 1D chain lie essentially in parallel to the bc plane to afford large open channels that are occupied by pyridine guest molecules (Figure b).

elements.content: X-ray Single-Crystal Structure of 2. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 2 adopts a complicated 2D polymeric structure and crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̄. The asymmetric unit consists of two cadmium atoms, three L ligands, and one coordinating nitrate group (Figure ). The L ligands adopt two different coordination modes:  one of them adopts an exo-tridentate linkage with a coordinating pyridyl group and a μ2, η2-carboxylate group, while the other two adopt an exo-tetradentate linkage with a coordinating pyridyl group and a μ2, η3-carboxylate group. The Cd1 center coordinates to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms, three carboxylate oxygen atoms, and one oxygen atom of the nitrate group, whereas the Cd2 center coordinates to one pyridyl nitrogen atom and five carboxylate oxygen atoms. Both Cd1 and Cd2 centers adopt a highly distorted octahedral geometry (Table ), and form edge-sharing bioctahdron via the two bridging oxygen atoms of the μ2, η3-carboxylate group (O1 and O6).

The Cd1 center coordinates to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms, three carboxylate oxygen atoms, and one oxygen atom of the nitrate group, whereas the Cd2 center coordinates to one pyridyl nitrogen atom and five carboxylate oxygen atoms. elements.content: The dicadmium moiety shown in Figure is further expanded via an inversion symmetry to generate a tetracadmium building unit (Figure ). Each tetracadmium building unit is then quadruply bridged by the L ligands to two tetracadmium building units in the horizontal direction and doubly bridged by the L ligands to two other tetracadmium building units in the vertical direction to form a complex 2D polymeric network (Figure ). These 2D structures effectively pack to leave no cavity for the inclusion of solvent molecules.

elements.content: X-ray Single-Crystal Structure of 3. Compound 3 also adopts a complicated 2D polymeric structure and crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic space group P21. The asymmetric unit consists of four cadmium atoms, six L ligands, two coordinating perchlorate groups, two coordinating methanol molecules, and one water guest molecule (Figure ). The L ligands adopt two different coordination modes:  two of them adopt an exo-tridentate linkage with a coordinating pyridyl group and a μ2, η2-carboxylate group, while the other four adopt an exo-tetradentate linkage with a coordinating pyridyl group and a μ2, η3-carboxylate group. There exist two distinct Cd coordination environments in 3. The Cd1 center adopts a distorted octahedral geometry by coordinating to two pyridyl nitrogen atoms, three carboxylate oxygen atoms, and one perchlorate oxygen atom, whereas the Cd2 center adopts a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry by coordinating to one pyridyl nitrogen atom, five carboxylate oxygen atoms, and one methanol oxygen atom (Table ). The Cd3 center adopts a coordination environment essentially the same to that of the Cd1 center, while the Cd4 center adopts a coordination environment essentially the same to that of the Cd2 center.

elements.content: The Cd1 octahedron and Cd2 pentagonal bipyramid share a common edge defined by the O3 and O6 atoms (Figure a). Similarly, the Cd3 octahedron and Cd4 pentagonal bipyramid are also edge-sharing. These edge-sharing dicadmium units serve as the secondary building units for the formation of a complex 2D coordination network of 3. Each dicadmium building unit is doubly bridged by the L ligands to two adjacent dicadmium building units and singly bridged by the L ligands to two other dicadmium building units to form a 2D polymeric network (Figure a). The 2D layers are effectively packed through 21 operations along the b axis and there exists void spaces for only one included water molecule per formula unit (Figure b).

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized and structurally characterized three new zinc and cadmium coordination polymers based 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoate bridging ligands. Compound 1 adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles, while 2 and 3 adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively. The locations of both pyridyl and carboxylate functionalities in meta positions in the present ligand have apparently lent greater flexibility, and thus allowed the formation of 1D chains in 1 and complicated 2D networks in 2 and 3. These results are in stark contrast to our previous reports on the synthesis of 2D polymeric networks of M(pyridinecarboxylate)2 where only one of the pyridyl and carboxylate functional groups is located in meta position.

Compound 1 adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles, while 2 and 3 adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively. The locations of both pyridyl and carboxylate functionalities in meta positions in the present ligand have apparently lent greater flexibility, and thus allowed the formation of 1D chains in 1 and complicated 2D networks in 2 and 3. These results are in stark contrast to our previous reports on the synthesis of 2D polymeric networks of M(pyridinecarboxylate)2 where only one of the pyridyl and carboxylate functional groups is located in meta position.

Synthesis of E -3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile. A mixture of (3-cyanobenzyl)triphenylphosphonium bromide (7.90 g, 17.2 mmol) and 3-pyridinecarbaldehyde (1.71 g, 16.0 mmol) in 25 mL of methylene chloride was stirred vigorously in a 250 mL Erlenmeyer flask. To this suspension was added 8 mL of 50% aqueous NaOH dropwise over the course of 1 h. After the sample was stirred vigorously for one additional hour, the mixture was diluted with 50 mL of methylene chloride and washed with three portions of deionized water (100 mL). The organic layer was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness. The residue was transferred to a 100 mL round-bottom flask containing iodine crystals (0.1 g, 0.788 mmol) and 50 mL of nitrobenzene, and the mixture was refluxed overnight. Upon cooling, the reaction mixture was extracted with dilute hydrochloric acid. The aqueous phase was removed, made alkaline with 3 M NaOH, and extracted with ethyl acetate. The extract was dried over MgSO4 and evaporated to dryness, and then purified by silica gel column chromatography (EtAc/hexane:  1/1) to afford 2.17 g of E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (51.7% yield). 1H NMR (CDCl3):  δ 8.60 (d, 4 J = 1.8 Hz, 1H, H1), 8.39 (dd, 3 J = 4.4 Hz, 4 J = 1.8 Hz, 1H, H2), 7.70 (dt, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 4 J = 1.6 Hz, 1H, H9), 7.62 (d, 4 J = 1.6 Hz, 1H, H10), 7.59 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H4), 7.39 (d, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H7), 7.32 (dd, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 1H, H8), 7.16 (dd, 3 J = 7.8 Hz, 3 J = 4.4 Hz, 1H, H3), 6.96 (s, 2H, H5 and H6). 13C {1H} NMR (CDCl3):  δ 148.8, 148.2, 137.4, 132.5, 131.6, 130.7, 130.2, 129.5, 129.1, 127.7, 127.0, 123.2, 118.2, 112.4.

Synthesis of [Zn(L) 2 ]·(py), 1. A mixture of Zn(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.038 g, 0.125 mmol) and E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (0.052 g, 0.25 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with EtOH (1.25 mL), H2O (0.25 mL), and pyridine (0.25 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen and sealed under vacuum, and placed inside an oven at 140 °C. After 40 days of heating, crystalline products of 1 were obtained. Yield:  0.048 g (64.8%). IR (cm-1):  3462 (m, br), 3030 (w), 2965 (w), 1606(m), 1589 (m), 1551(s), 1483 (m), 1410(m), 1400 (s), 1225 (m), 1194 (m), 1131 (w), 1087 (w), 1059 (s), 1029 (w), 993 (w), 962 (m), 927 (w), 874 (w), 824 (s) 803 (s), 772 (s), 760 (m), 649 (m), 604 (w), 548 (w).

Synthesis of [Cd 2 (L) 3 (NO 3 )], 2. A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.039 g, 0.125 mmol) and E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (0.052 g, 0.25 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with EtOH (1.0 mL), H2O (0.25 mL), and pyridine (0.25 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen and sealed under vacuum, and placed inside an oven at 120 °C. After 30 days of heating, crystalline products of 2 were obtained. Yield:  0.023 g (38%). IR (cm-1):  3434 (m, br), 3029 (w), 2968 (w), 1608(m), 1589 (m), 1563(s), 1552 (ms), 1483 (w), 1451 (m), 1426 (w), 1390 (s), 1295 (m), 1195 (w), 1183 (w), 1124 (w), 1085 (w), 1060 (s), 1030 (w), 964 (m), 925 (w), 870 (w), 824 (w), 797 (m), 761 (m), 760 (ms), 670 (m), 642 (w), 531 (w).

Synthesis of [Cd 4 (L) 6 (ClO 4 ) 2 (MeOH) 2 ]·(H 2 O), 3. A mixture of Cd(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.053 g, 0.125 mmol) and E-3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile (0.052 g, 0.025 mmol) was thoroughly mixed with MeOH (1.0 mL) and H2O (0.25 mL) in a heavy-walled Pyrex tube. The tube was frozen and sealed under vacuum, and placed inside an oven at 130 °C. After 4 days of heating, crystalline products of 3 were obtained. Yield:  0.024 g (37%). IR (cm-1):  3488 (m, br), 3060 (w), 2968 (w), 1604(m), 1586 (m), 1559(s), 1483 (w), 1426 (m), 1389 (s), 1266 (w), 1127 (w), 1188 (w), 1100(m), 1070 (m), 1045 (m), 960 (m), 856 (w), 801 (m), 764 (m), 701 (m), 681 (m), 641 (w), 621 (w), 531 (w).

cln_elements.content: New zinc(II) and cadmium(II) coordination polymers with 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoato (L) bridging ligands have been synthesized by treating the metal salts and 3-[2-(3-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzonitrile under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions. [Zn(L)2]·(pyridine), 1, adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles. Large open channels formed in 1 are filled with included pyridine guest molecules. Both [Cd2(L)3(NO3)], 2, and [Cd4(L)6(ClO4)2(MeOH)2]·(H2O), 3, adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively. Crystal data for 1:  triclinic space group P1̄, a = 8.601(1), b = 12.364(1), c = 14.224(1) Å, α = 72.687(1), β = 88.118(1), γ = 71.679(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 2:  triclinic space group P1̄, a = 10.675(1), b = 12.671(1), c = 14.838(1) Å, α = 74.772(1), β = 88.283(1), γ = 73.671(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 3:  monoclinic space group P21, a = 13.165(3), b = 20.119(9), c = 15.446(6) Å, β = 95.19(3), Z = 2.

[Zn(L)2]⋅(pyridine), 1, adopts a 1D polymeric structure built from mutually perpendicular 22-membered macrocycles. Large open channels formed in 1 are filled with included pyridine guest molecules. Both [Cd2(L)3(NO3)], 2, and [Cd4(L)6(ClO4)2(MeOH)2]⋅(H2O), 3, adopt complicated 2D polymeric structures that are built from carboxylate-bridged tetracadmium and dicadmium building units, respectively. Crystal data for 1: triclinic space group P1̄, a = 8.601(1), b = 12.364(1), c = 14.224(1) Å, α = 72.687(1), β = 88.118(1), γ = 71.679(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 2: triclinic space group P1̄, a = 10.675(1), b = 12.671(1), c = 14.838(1) Å, α = 74.772(1), β = 88.283(1), γ = 73.671(1)°, Z = 2. Crystal data for 3: monoclinic space group P21, a = 13.165(3), b = 20.119(9), c = 15.446(6) Å, β = 95.19(3), Z = 2.
